Origin: Accomac Shire was established in 1634 as one of the original eight shires of Virginia. In 1642, it was renamed Northampton County. Then in 1663, Northampton County was divided into two counties. The southern half remained Northampton County while the northern half became Accomac County -- later renamed Accomack with a "k."
Etymology: From the Native American word Accawmack, meaning "on the other side", referencing the county's position across Chesapeake Bay

Origin: In 1744, the Virginia General Assembly created Albemarle County by taking the northern portion of Goochland County.
Etymology: Willem Anne van Keppel, 2nd Earl of Albemarle, colonial proprietary governor

Origin: Formed from parts of Bath and Botetourt counties as well as Monroe County (now in WV)
Etymology: Alleghany Mountains

Origin: Formed from Brunswick and Prince George counties
Etymology: Princess Amelia Sophia, second daughter of George II of Great Britain
Jeffery Amherst, British conqueror of Quebec during the Seven Years' War and colonial governor of Virginia

Origin: From Buckingham, Campbell, Charlotte and Prince Edward counties
Etymology: Appomattox River

Origin: Annexed from the District of Columbia, having previously been part of Fairfax County prior to the district's formation
Etymology: Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial, originally called Alexandria County; renamed in 1920
Augusta of Saxe-Gotha, the Princess of Wales

Origin: From Augusta, Botetourt and Greenbrier counties May 1, 1791
Etymology: Bath, England
John Russell, 4th Duke of Bedford, British politician and one of the head negotiators of the Peace of Paris

Origin: From Giles, Tazewell, and Wythe counties
Etymology: Richard Bland, member of the Continental Congress and publisher of the American Revolutionary War-era tract An Inquiry into the Rights of the British Colonies
Norborne Berkeley, 4th Baron Botetourt, colonial governor of Virginia

Origin: From Prince George county. Parts of Surry and Isle of Wight counties were added in 1732 (when the county's government was established.)
Etymology: Duchy of Brunswick-Lüneburg, from which the current line of British monarchs hailed
James Buchanan, fifteenth U.S. President
Duke of Buckingham
William Campbell, Revolutionary War general

Origin: From Essex, King and Queen, and King William counties
Etymology: Caroline of Ansbach, wife of King George II of Great Britain
Charles Carroll of Carrollton
King Charles I of England
Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, wife of King George III of Great Britain
Philip Stanhope, 4th Earl of Chesterfield, British politician and Lord of the Bedchamber
George Rogers Clarke, Revolutionary War general

Origin: Formed from Botetourt, Roanoke, Giles, and Monroe (in present-day West Virginia) Counties
Etymology: Robert Craig, U.S. Representative from Virginia

Origin: Culpeper County was established in 1749 from Orange County, Virginia.
Etymology: Thomas Colepeper, 2nd Baron Colepeper, colonial proprietary governor
Prince William, Duke of Cumberland, British general, politician, and son of King George II

Origin: Formed from parts of Buchanan, Russell, and Wise Counties
Etymology: William J. Dickinson (1827-1907), member of the Virginia House of Delegates
Robert Dinwiddie, colonial lieutenant governor of Virginia

Origin: From the original Rappahannock County, Virginia, commonly known as Old Rappahannock County, which was split to form Essex and Richmond counties.
Etymology: Essex, United Kingdom
Thomas Fairfax, 6th Lord Fairfax of Cameron, the only British noble resident in Virginia
Francis Fauquier, colonial lieutenant governor of Virginia
John Floyd, governor of Virginia
From the Latin name for the James River, which itself translates to "Annie's River" in honor of Queen Anne

Origin: Formed from parts of Bedford and Henry Counties
Etymology: Benjamin Franklin, publisher, orator, scholar, and U.S. Founding Father
Frederick, Prince of Wales, eldest son of George II

Origin: Formed from Montgomery, Monroe, Wythe, and Tazewell Counties
Etymology: William Branch Giles, U.S. Senator from Virginia
Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester
William Gooch, colonial lieutenant governor of Virginia
William Grayson, U.S. Senator from Virginia
Nathanael Greene, Revolutionary War general
Richard Grenville, commander of the English expedition to found Roanoke Colony
George Montagu-Dunk, 2nd Earl of Halifax, President of the Board of Trade

Origin: From the area of New Kent County called St. Paul's Parish
Etymology: Electorate of Hanover, from which the current line of British monarchs hailed

Origin: Original county of the Colony under England
Etymology: Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales, oldest son of James I of England

Origin: From Pittsylvania County, it was initially named Patrick Henry County
Etymology: Patrick Henry, governor of Virginia and U.S. Founding Father
Mountainous topography

Origin: Original county of the Colony under England, initially named Warrosquyoake Shire
Etymology: Isle of Wight, England

Origin: Original county of the Colony under England
Etymology: King James I of England

Origin: King and Queen County was established in 1691 from New Kent County, Virginia.
Etymology: King William III and Queen Mary II
George I of Great Britain

Origin: English colonists formed King William County in 1702 out of King and Queen County, Virginia.
Etymology: William III of England

Origin: Lancaster County was established in 1651 from Northumberland and York counties.
Etymology: Lancaster, United Kingdom
Light Horse Harry Lee, Revolutionary War general and governor of Virginia
John Campbell, 4th Earl of Loudoun, British Commander-in-Chief, North America during the Seven Years' War
Princess Louise, youngest daughter of George II
Duchy of Brunswick-Lüneburg, from which the current line of British monarchs hailed
James Madison, Congressman from Virginia, principal author of the U.S. Constitution, and future U.S. President
Thomas Mathews, Revolutionary War general.
Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, wife of King George III
Middlesex, United Kingdom
Richard Montgomery, Revolutionary War general
Thomas Nelson Jr., governor of Virginia and signer of the Declaration of Independence

Origin: New Kent County was established in 1654 from York County, Virginia.
Etymology: Kent County, England

Origin: Original county of the Colony under England, initially named Accomac Shire. In 1642, it was renamed Northampton County. However, in 1663, Northampton County was divided into two counties. The southern half remained Northampton County while the northern half once again became Accomac County -- later spelled Accomack.
Etymology: Northamptonshire, England

Origin: The county was created by the Virginia General Assembly in 1648 during a period of rapid population growth and geographic expansion.
Etymology: Northumberland, United Kingdom

Origin: From the area of Amelia County called Nottaway Parish
Etymology: Nodawa tribe

Origin: Settlers established the legal entity of Orange County in 1734 from a portion of Spotsylvania County, Virginia.
Etymology: William IV, Prince of Orange, to celebrate his marriage to the Royal Princess Anne of the House of Hanover, England on March 25, 1734. The county was formed on August 8, 1734
John Page, governor of Virginia
Patrick Henry, governor of Virginia and U.S. Founding Father
William Pitt, British Prime Minister
Powhatan tribe
Prince Edward, Duke of York and Albany, brother of George III
Prince George of Denmark, the husband of Queen Anne

Origin: From Stafford and King George counties
Etymology: Prince William Augustus, son of George II
Kazimierz Pulaski, Polish-born Revolutionary War general

Origin: From Culpeper County. The original Rappahannock County, known as Old Rappahannock County, was created in 1656 from part of Lancaster County. Old Rappahannock County became extinct in 1692 when it was split to create Essex and Richmond counties.
Etymology: Rappahannock River

Origin: From the original Rappahannock County, better known as Old Rappahannock County, which was split to form Richmond and Essex counties.
Etymology: Charles Lennox, 1st Duke of Richmond, illegitimate son of King Charles II

Origin: From the southern part of Botetourt County
Etymology: Roanoke River

Origin: From parts of Augusta and Botetourt counties
Etymology: Natural Bridge
Charles Watson-Wentworth, 2nd Marquess of Rockingham, British Prime Minister

Origin: From a section of Washington County
Etymology: William Russell, frontiersman and state representative

Origin: Formed from parts of Washington, Lee, and Russell Counties
Etymology: Winfield Scott, War of 1812 and later Mexican-American War general

Origin: Formed from non-county territory; originally named for Governor John Murray, 4th Earl of Dunmore, but renamed in 1778.
Etymology: Shenandoah River
Alexander Smyth, Congressman from Virginia

Origin: Most of it from part of Warrosquyoake Shire
Etymology: Disputed; either Southampton, England or Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton, one of the founders of the Virginia Company

Origin: Spotsylvania County was established in 1721 from Essex, King and Queen, and King William counties.
Etymology: Alexander Spotswood, colonial lieutenant governor of Virginia
Stafford, England

Origin: From part of James City County
Etymology: Surrey, United Kingdom
Sussex, United Kingdom

Origin: From portions of Wythe and Russell counties
Etymology: Henry Tazewell, U.S. Senator from Virginia
Joseph Warren, Revolutionary War general
George Washington, Revolutionary War commander, U.S. Founding Father, and future U.S. President
Westmoreland, United Kingdom

Origin: From Lee, Scott, and Russell Counties
Etymology: Henry Alexander Wise, governor of Virginia
George Wythe, legal scholar and signer of the Declaration of Independence

Origin: Formed in 1634 as one of the eight shires of Virginia. It was originally called Charles River Shire.
Etymology: James Stuart, Duke of York, the future King James II
